info.text: The default category for questions shared in context '11.4 Differentiating Products and Quotients'.

questiontext.text:
The product rule with three factors Produktregelen med tre faktorer

The rule for differentiating a product can be extended to any number of products. If, for example, \(y = f(x)g(x)h(x)\) then \begin{align} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{df}{dx} [g(x)h(x)] + f(x)\dfrac{d}{dx}[g(x)h(x)] \\ &= \dfrac{df}{dx}g(x)h(x) + f(x) \left\{ \dfrac{dg}{dx}h(x) + g(x)\dfrac{dh}{dx} \right\} \\ &= \dfrac{df}{dx}g(x)h(x) + f(x)\dfrac{dg}{dx}h(x) + f(x)g(x)\dfrac{dh}{dx} \end{align} That is, each function in the product is differentiated in turn and the three results added together. Regelen for å derivere et produkt kan utvides til så mange produkter som du vil. Hvis for eksempel \(y = f(x)g(x)h(x)\), så er \begin{align} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{df}{dx} [g(x)h(x)] + f(x)\dfrac{d}{dx}[g(x)h(x)] \\ &= \dfrac{df}{dx}g(x)h(x) + f(x) \left\{ \dfrac{dg}{dx}h(x) + g(x)\dfrac{dh}{dx} \right\} \\ &= \dfrac{df}{dx}g(x)h(x) + f(x)\dfrac{dg}{dx}h(x) + f(x)g(x)\dfrac{dh}{dx} \end{align} Det vil si at hver funksjon i produktet blir derivert i tur og orden, og de tre resultatene blir lagt sammen.

Example Eksempel

If \(y = x e^{2x} \sin x\) then find \( \dfrac{dy}{dx}\). Hvis \(y = x e^{2x} \sin x\), så finn \(\dfrac{dy}{dx}\).

Solution Løsning

Here \[ f(x) = x, g(x) = e^{2x}, h(x) = \sin x \] \[ \dfrac{df}{dx} = 1, \dfrac{dg}{dx} = 2e^{2x},\dfrac{dh}{dx} = \cos x, \] \[ \therefore \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 1(e^{2x} \sin x) + x(2e^{2x}) \sin x + xe^{2x}(\cos x)\] \[ = e^{2x}(\sin x + 2x \sin x + x \cos x) \] Her \[ f(x) = x, g(x) = e^{2x}, h(x) = \sin x \] \[ \dfrac{df}{dx} = 1, \dfrac{dg}{dx} = 2e^{2x},\dfrac{dh}{dx} = \cos x, \] \[ \therefore \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 1(e^{2x} \sin x) + x(2e^{2x}) \sin x + xe^{2x}(\cos x)\] \[ = e^{2x}(\sin x + 2x \sin x + x \cos x) \]

Differentiating a product Å differensiere et produkt

In previous Sections we have examined the process of differentiating functions. We found how to obtain the derivative of many commonly occurring functions. These are recorded in the following table (remember, arguments of trigonometric functions are assumed to be in radians). I tidligere seksjoner har vi undersøkt prosessen med å differensiere funksjoner. Vi fant ut hvordan vi kunne finne den deriverte av mange vanlig forekommende funksjoner. Disse er registrert i følgende tabell (husk at argumentene til trigonometriske funksjoner antas å være i radianer).

\(y\) \( \dfrac{dy}{dx}\)
\(x^n\) \(nx^{n-1}\)
\(\sin ax\) \(a \cos ax\)
\(\cos ax\) \(-a \sin ax\)
\(\tan ax\) \(a\sec^2 x\)
\( \sec ax \) \(a \sec ax \tan ax\)
\(\ln ax\) \(\dfrac{1}{x}\)
\(e^{ax}\) \(ae^{ax}\)
\(\cosh ax\) \(a \sinh ax\)
\(\sinh ax\) \( a \cosh ax\)

In this Section we consider how to differentiate non-standard functions - in particular those which can be written as the product of standard functions. Being able to differentiate such functions depends upon the following Key Point. I denne seksjonen vil vi se på hvordan vi kan deriverere ikke-standard funksjoner, spesielt de som kan skrives som produkt av standard funksjoner. Evnen til å deriverere slike funksjoner avhenger av følgende nøkkelpunkt.

Key Point Nøkkelpunkt

Product Rule Produktregelen

If \(y(x) = f(x)g(x)\) then \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{df}{dx}g(x) + f(x)\dfrac{dg}{dx}\text{ or }y' = f'g + fg'.\] Hvis \(y(x) = f(x)g(x)\) så er \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{df}{dx}g(x) + f(x)\dfrac{dg}{dx}\text{ eller }y' = f'g + fg'.\]

In slightly more compact notation this is if \(y = uv\) then \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}\text{ or }y' = uv' + vu' .\] Med litt mer kompakt notasjon betyr dette at hvis \(y = uv\), så er \[\dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}\text{ eller }y' = uv' + vu'.\]

It is not difficult to prove this from the limit definition of the derivative and it can be an instructive exercise to do so (hint: write the right hand side as a limit of a single ratio).  We shall concentrate on its use. Det er ikke vanskelig å bevise dette fra grense-definisjonen av den deriverte, og det kan være en lærerik øvelse å gjøre det (tips: skriv høyresiden som en grense av en enkelt ratio). Vi skal konsentrere oss om bruken av formelen.

Example Eksempel

Differentiate Differentier

  1. \(y = x^2 \sin x \)
  2. \(y = x \ln x\)

Solution Løsning

  1. Writing \(f(x) = x^2\), \(g(x) = \sin x\), we haveÂ  \(\dfrac{df}{dx}= 2x; \dfrac{dg}{dx}= \cos x\) and so \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 2x(\sin x) + x^2(\cos x) = x(2 \sin x + x \cos x). \) Skriver \(f(x) = x^2\), \(g(x) = \sin x\), har vi \(\dfrac{df}{dx}= 2x; \dfrac{dg}{dx}= \cos x\) og dermed blir \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 2x(\sin x) + x^2(\cos x) = x(2 \sin x + x \cos x). \)

  2. Writing \(f(x) = x\), \(g(x) = \ln x\), we haveÂ  \(\dfrac{df}{dx}= 1; \dfrac{dg}{dx}= \dfrac{1}{x}\) Skriver vi \(f(x) = x\), \(g(x) = \ln x\), har vi \(\dfrac{df}{dx}= 1; \dfrac{dg}{dx}= \dfrac{1}{x}\).

    and so \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 1(\ln x) + x \left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right) = \ln x + 1.\) og så \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = 1(\ln x) + x \left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right) = \ln x + 1.\)

Differentiating a quotient Derivasjon av en kvotient

In this Section we consider functions of the form \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\). To find the derivative of such a function we make use of the following Key Point: I denne seksjonen vil vi se på funksjoner på formen \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\). For å finne den deriverte av en slik funksjon, bruker vi følgende viktige punkt:

Key Point Nøkkelpunkt

Quotient Rule Kvotientregelen

If \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), then \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ g(x) \dfrac{df}{dx} - \dfrac{dg}{dx}f(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\] or \(y' = \dfrac{ gf' - g'f}{g^2}\). Hvis \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), så er \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ g(x) \dfrac{df}{dx} - \dfrac{dg}{dx}f(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\] eller \(y' = \dfrac{ gf' - g'f}{g^2}\).

In slightly more compact notation we have that if \(y = \dfrac{u}{v}\), then \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ v \dfrac{du}{dx} - \dfrac{dv}{dx}u}{v^2}\] or \(y' = \dfrac{ vu' - v'u}{v^2}\).  I litt mer kompakt notasjon har vi at dersom \(y = \dfrac{u}{v}\), så har vi at \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ v \dfrac{du}{dx} - \dfrac{dv}{dx}u}{v^2}\] eller \(y' = \dfrac{ vu' - v'u}{v^2}\).

These are two equivalent versions of the quotient rule. Dette er to ekvivalente versjoner av kvote-regelen.


Example Eksempel

Find the derivative of \(y = \dfrac{\ln x}{x}\). Finn den deriverte av \(y = \dfrac{\ln x}{x}\)

Solution Løsning

Here \(f(x) = \ln x\) and \(g(x) = x\) \[ \therefore \dfrac{df}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{x} \text{ and } \dfrac{dg}{dx} = 1 \] Hence \(\dfrac{dy}{dx} =\dfrac{x \left( \dfrac{1}{x} \right) - 1(\ln x) }{[x]^2} = \dfrac{1 - \ln x}{x^2}\) Her er \(f(x) = \ln x\) og \(g(x) = x\) \[ \therefore \dfrac{df}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{x} \text{ og } \dfrac{dg}{dx} = 1 \] Derfor \(\dfrac{dy}{dx} =\dfrac{x \left( \dfrac{1}{x} \right) - 1(\ln x) }{[x]^2} = \dfrac{1 - \ln x}{x^2}\)

Note that the product rule can also be used to differentiate this function by writing it in the form \(y = f(x)g(x) = (\ln x)(x^{-1})\). Merk at produktregelen kan også bli brukt for å derivere denne funksjonen ved å skrive den på formen \(y = f(x)g(x) = (\ln x)(x^{-1})\).

Exercise Oppgave

In each case find the derivative of the function I hvert tilfelle finn den deriverte av funksjonen.

  1. \( y ={@f1(x)@}{@g1(x)@} \) \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \( y ={@f2(x)@}{@g2(x)@} \) \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]
  3. \( y =\sin^2 x \) \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]
  4. \( y ={@f4(x)@}{@g4(x)@} \) \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. We have \(y = f(x)g(x)\), with \( f(x) = {@f1(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g1(x)@} \). Vi har \(y = f(x)g(x)\), der \( f(x) = {@f1(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = {@g1(x)@} \).

    Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df1@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg1@}}\). Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df1@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg1@}}\).

    So \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df1@}({@g1(x)@}) + {@f1(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg1@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta1@}}\) Så er \(\dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df1@}({@g1(x)@}) + {@f1(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg1@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta1@}}\)

  2. We have \(y = f(x)g(x)\), with \( f(x) = {@f2(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g2(x)@} \). Vi har \(y = f(x)g(x)\), med \(f(x) = {@f2(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = {@g2(x)@}\).

    Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df2@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg2@}}\). Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df2@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg2@}}\).

    So \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df2@}({@g2(x)@}) + {@f2(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg2@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\) Så \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df2@}({@g2(x)@}) + {@f2(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg2@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\)

  3. We have \(y = f(x)g(x)\), with \( f(x) = {@f3(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g3(x)@} \). Vi har \(y = f(x)g(x)\), der \(f(x) = {@f3(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = {@g3(x)@}\).

    Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df3@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg3@}}\). Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df3@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg3@}}\).

    So \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df3@}({@g3(x)@}) + {@f3(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg3@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}\) Så \(\dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df3@}({@g3(x)@}) + {@f3(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg3@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}\)

  4. We have \(y = f(x)g(x)\), with \( f(x) = {@f4(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g4(x)@} \). Vi har \( y = f(x)g(x) \), der \( f(x) = {@f4(x)@} \) og \( g(x) = {@g4(x)@} \).

    Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df4@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg4@}}\). Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df4@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg4@}}\).

    So \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df4@}({@g4(x)@}) + {@f4(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg4@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta4@}}\) Så \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@df4@}({@g4(x)@}) + {@f4(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg4@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta4@}}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øvelse

In each case find the derivative of the function I hvert tilfelle finn den deriverte av funksjonen

  1. \( y =\dfrac{x}{\cos (x)} \) (recall that \( \dfrac{1}{\cos(x)}=\sec(x)\) \( y =\dfrac{x}{\cos (x)} \) (husk at \( \dfrac{1}{\cos(x)}=\sec(x)\))

    \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

  2. \( y ={@f2(x)@}{@g2(x)@} \)

    \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

  3. Obtain the derivative of \(y = x e^{x} \tan x \) by using your answers to part (a) and (b) Finn den deriverte av \(y = x e^{x} \tan x \) ved å bruke svarene fra del (a) og (b).

    \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. We have \(y = f(x)g(x)\), with \( f(x) = {@f1(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = \displaystyle {@g1(x)@} .\) Vi har \(y = f(x)g(x)\), med \(f(x) = {@f1(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = \displaystyle {@g1(x)@} .\)

    Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df1@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg1@}} .\) Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df1@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg1@}} .\)

    So \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= {@df1@}\left({@g1(x)@}\right) +{@f1(x)@} \left( \displaystyle{{@dg1@}} \right) \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta1@}}. \end{align*}\] Så \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= {@df1@}\left({@g1(x)@}\right) +{@f1(x)@} \left( \displaystyle{{@dg1@}} \right) \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta1@}}. \end{align*}\]

  2. We have \(y = f(x)g(x)\), with \( f(x) = {@f2(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g2(x)@} .\) Vi har \(y = f(x)g(x)\), der \( f(x) = {@f2(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = {@g2(x)@}.\)

    Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df2@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg2@}}.\) Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@df2@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg2@}}.\)

    So \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= {@df2@}(\displaystyle{{@g2(x)@}}) + {@f2(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg2@}}) \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}. \end{align*}\] Så \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= {@df2@}(\displaystyle{{@g2(x)@}}) + {@f2(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg2@}}) \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}. \end{align*}\]

  3. The derivative of \(y = x e^{ x} \tan x = \dfrac{x}{\cos x} e^{x} \sin x \) is found by applying the product rule to the results of parts (a) and (b). Den deriverte av \(y = x e^{x} \tan x = \dfrac{x}{\cos x} e^{x} \sin x\) finnes ved å anvende produktregelen på resultatene fra del (a) og (b).

    So we have \(y = f(x)g(x)\), with \( f(x) = \displaystyle{{@f3(x)@}}\) and \(g(x) = {@g3(x)@} .\) Vi har altså \(y = f(x)g(x)\), der \( f(x) = \displaystyle{{@f3(x)@}}\) og \(g(x) = {@g3(x)@} .\)

    Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@df3@}} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg3@}}.\) Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@df3@}} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@dg3@}}.\)

    So \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \displaystyle{{@df3@}}(\displaystyle{{@g3(x)@}}) + {@f3(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg3@}}) \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}. \end{align*}\] Så \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \displaystyle{{@df3@}}(\displaystyle{{@g3(x)@}}) + {@f3(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@dg3@}}) \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}. \end{align*}\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Oppgave


Here we are going to find the first derivative of \(y = e^x \ln x\). Her skal vi finne den første deriverte til \(y=e^x\ln x\).

We can see that the two functions are  Vi kan se at de to funksjonene er

\[ f(x) = e^x \hspace{1cm} g(x) = \ln x \] \[f(x) = e^x \hspace{1cm} g(x) = \ln x\].

Now find the derivative of each of these functions  Nå finn den deriverte av hver av disse funksjonene

\( \dfrac{df}{dx} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]] \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

Finally, we have  Til slutt har vi

\( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
We have \(y = f(x)g(x)= e^x \ln x\), with \( f(x) = {@f(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g(x)@} \). Vi har \(y = f(x)g(x)= e^x \ln x\), hvor \( f(x) = {@f(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = {@g(x)@} \).

Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\). Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\).

So \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@ta1@}({@g(x)@}) + {@f(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@ta2@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}\) Så \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = {@ta1@}({@g(x)@}) + {@f(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@ta2@}}) = \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Oppgave

Here we are going to find the first derivative of \(y(x) = \displaystyle {@y_x@}.\) Her skal vi finne den første deriverte av \(y(x) = \displaystyle {@y_x@}.\)

We can factorise \(y(x)\) into the two factors  Vi kan faktorisere \(y(x)\) inn i to faktorer.

\[ f(x) = {@f_x@} \hspace{1cm} g(x) = {@g_x@}. \] \[ f(x) = {@f_x@} \hspace{1cm} g(x) = {@g_x@}. \]

Now find the derivative of each of these factors. Finn nå den deriverte av hver av disse faktorene.

\( \dfrac{df}{dx} = \)

[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

\( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

Finally, substitute into the product rule to determine Til slutt, sett inn i produktregelen for å bestemme.

\( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
We have \(y = f(x)g(x)= \displaystyle {@y_x@}\), with \( f(x) = {@f_x@}\) and \(g(x) = \displaystyle {@g_x@} = x^{@-a1@}\).

Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\).

So \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{df}{dx} g(x)+ f(x) \dfrac{dg}{dx}\\ &= \displaystyle {@diff(y_x,x)@}\\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}. \end{align*}\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Oppgave

Here we are going to find the first derivative of \(y = x^2(\ln x) \sinh x\). Her skal vi finne den første deriverte av \(y = x^2(\ln x) \sinh x\).

We can see that the three functions are  Vi kan se at de tre funksjonene er

\[ f(x) = x^2, \hspace{1cm} g(x) = \ln x, \hspace{1cm} h(x) = \sinh x. \] \[ f(x) = x^2,\hspace{1cm} g(x) = \ln x, \hspace{1cm} h(x) = \sinh x. \]

Now find the derivative of each of these functions  Nå finn den deriverte til hver av disse funksjonene.

\( \dfrac{df}{dx} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

\( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

\( \dfrac{dh}{dx} = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

Finally, we have  Endelig har vi

\( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
We are having the function \(y = f(x) g(x) h(x)= x^2(\ln x) \sinh x.\) Vi har funksjonen \(y = f(x) g(x) h(x)= x^2(\ln x) \sinh x.\)

We can see that the three functions are: \( f(x) = x^2, \hspace{1cm} g(x) = \ln x, \hspace{1cm} h(x) = \sinh x. \) Vi kan se at de tre funksjonene er: \( f(x) = x^2, \hspace{1cm} g(x) = \ln x, \hspace{1cm} h(x) = \sinh x. \)

The derivatives of each of these functions are: Derivatene av hver av disse funksjonene er:

\[ \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@},\hspace{1cm} \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{@ta2@}, \hspace{1cm} \dfrac{dh}{dx} ={@ta3@}\] \[ \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@},\hspace{1cm} \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{@ta2@}, \hspace{1cm} \dfrac{dh}{dx} ={@ta3@}\]

Finally, we have: \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{df}{dx} g(x)h(x)+ f(x) \dfrac{dg}{dx} h(x) + f(x)g(x) \dfrac{dh}{dx} \\ &= {@ta4@}. \end{align*}\] Til slutt har vi: \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{df}{dx} g(x)h(x)+ f(x) \dfrac{dg}{dx} h(x) + f(x)g(x) \dfrac{dh}{dx} \\ &= {@ta4@}. \end{align*}\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

questiontext.text:
Exercise Oppgave

Find the derivative of \(y = \displaystyle{{@y(x)@}}\) using the quotient rule. Finn den deriverte av \(y = \displaystyle{{@y(x)@}}\) ved hjelp av kvotientregelen.

We can see that the two functions are  Vi kan se at de to funksjonene er

\[ f(x) = {@f(x)@} \hspace{1cm} g(x) = {@g(x)@} \]

Now find the derivative of each of these functions  Nå finn derivert av hver av disse funksjonene.

\( \dfrac{df}{dx} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]] \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

Finally, we have  Endelig har vi

\( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
We have \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), with \( f(x) = {@f(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g(x)@} \). Vi har \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), hvor \( f(x) = {@f(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = {@g(x)@} \).

Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\). Da er \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\).

So \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{ ({@g(x)@})(\displaystyle{{@ta1@}}) - \displaystyle{({@ta2@})}({@f(x)@})} {{@g(x)^2@}} \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}. \end{align*}\] Så \[\begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{ ({@g(x)@})(\displaystyle{{@ta1@}}) - \displaystyle{({@ta2@})}({@f(x)@})} {{@g(x)^2@}} \\ &= \displaystyle{{@ta3@}}. \end{align*}\]

questiontext.text:
Exercise Øvelse

Here we are going to find the first derivative of \(y = \displaystyle{{@y(x)@}}\) using the quotient rule. Her skal vi finne den første deriverte av \(y = \displaystyle{{@y(x)@}}\) ved bruk av kvotientregelen.

We can see that the two functions are  Vi kan se at de to funksjonene er

\[ f(x) = {@f(x)@}, \hspace{1cm} g(x) = {@g(x)@}. \]]

Now find the derivative of each of these functions. Finn nå den deriverte av hver av disse funksjonene.

\( \dfrac{df}{dx} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]] \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

Finally, we have  Endelig har vi

\( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
We have \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), with \( f(x) = {@f(x)@}\) and \(g(x) = {@g(x)@} \). Vi har \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), hvor \(f(x) = {@f(x)@}\) og \(g(x) = {@g(x)@}\).

Then, \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@} \) and \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\). Da blir \( \dfrac{df}{dx} = {@ta1@} \) og \( \dfrac{dg}{dx} = \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}\).

So \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ {@g(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@ta1@}}) - \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}({@f(x)@})} {{@g(x)^2@}} = \displaystyle{{@ta3@}} .\) Så \( \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ {@g(x)@}(\displaystyle{{@ta1@}}) - \displaystyle{{@ta2@}}({@f(x)@})} {{@g(x)^2@}} = \displaystyle{{@ta3@}} .\)
